I.name: I
I.definition: usually for orchestral string instruments, used to indicate that the player should play the passage on the highest-pitched, thinnest string

2 ′.definition: two feet – pipe organ indication; see Organ stop § Pitch and length

2 + 2⁄3 ′.definition: pipe organ stop for the twelfth interval

II.name: II
II.definition: usually for orchestral string instruments, used to indicate that the player should play the passage on the second highest string

II cymbal stop on pipe organ.name: II cymbal stop on pipe organ
II cymbal stop on pipe organ.definition: a stop that produces a sound resembling cymbals

III.name: III
III.definition: usually for orchestral string instruments, used to indicate that the player should play the passage on the third-highest string

4 ′.definition: four feet – pipe organ rank that speaks one octave higher than 8 ′

IV.name: IV
IV.definition: usually for orchestral string instruments, used to indicate that the player should play the passage on the lowest-pitched, thickest string, i.e. the fourth-highest string

16 ′.definition: sixteen-foot pipe – pipe organ indication calling for one octave below 8 ′

32 ′.definition: thirty-two-foot pipe – pipe organ indication calling for two octaves below 8 ′ also called sub-bass

64 ′.definition: sixty-four-foot pipe – pipe organ indication (only a few organs have this deep a pitch)

a battuta.name: a battuta
a battuta.definition: Return to normal tempo after a deviation. Not recommended in string parts, due to possible confusion with battuto (qv.); use a tempo, which means the same thing

a cappella.name: a cappella
a cappella.definition: lit. 'in a chapel'; vocal parts only, without instrumental accompaniment

a capriccio.name: a capriccio
a capriccio.definition: A free and capricious approach to tempo

a due (a 2).name: a due (a 2)
a due (a 2).definition: intended as a duet; for two voices or instruments; together; two instruments are to play in unison after a solo passage for one of the instruments

a niente.name: a niente
a niente.definition: To nothing; indicating a diminuendo which fades completely away

a piacere.name: a piacere
a piacere.definition: At pleasure (i.e. the performer need not follow the rhythm strictly, for example in a cadenza)

a prima vista.name: a prima vista
a prima vista.definition: lit. 'at first sight'. Sight-reading (i.e. played or sung from written notation but without prior review of the written material; refer to the figure)

a tempo.name: a tempo
a tempo.definition: In time (i.e. the performer should return to the stable tempo, such as after an accelerando or ritardando ); also may be found in combination with other terms such as a tempo giusto (in strict time) or a tempo di menuetto (at the speed of a minuet)

abafando (Port.).name: abafando (Port.)
abafando (Port.).definition: Muffling, dampening (i.e. on a drum, muted with a cloth)

acciaccatura.name: acciaccatura
acciaccatura.definition: Crushing (i.e. a very fast grace note that is 'crushed' against the note that follows and takes up no value in the measure)

accidental.name: accidental
accidental.definition: A note that is not part of the scale indicated by the key signature

accompagnato.name: accompagnato
accompagnato.definition: Accompanied (i.e. with the accompaniment following the soloist, who may speed up or slow down at will)

acoustic.name: acoustic
acoustic.definition: Relating to music produced by instruments, as opposed to electric or electronic means

ad libitum (ad lib.).name: ad libitum (ad lib.)
ad libitum (ad lib.).definition: At liberty (i.e. the speed and manner of execution are left to the performer. It can also mean improvisation .)

adagissimo.name: adagissimo
adagissimo.definition: Very, very slow (20 bpm and below)

affettuoso, affettuosamente,\nor con aff.name: affettuoso, affettuosamente, or con affetto
affettuoso, affettuosamente,\nor con aff.definition: With affect (that is, with emotion); see also con amore

al, alla.name: al, alla
al, alla.definition: To the, in the manner of ( al before masculine nouns, alla before feminine)

al fine.name: al fine
al fine.definition: To the end (i.e. an instruction to repeat the previous section of music, often using a dal segno or da capo, until reaching the final barline or the word 'fine')

al segno.name: al segno
al segno.definition: To the sign (i.e. return to a place in the music designated by the sign )

allegro.name: allegro
allegro.definition: Cheerful or brisk; but commonly interpreted as lively, fast

allentando.name: allentando
allentando.definition: Slowing down; decelerating; opposite of accelerando (same as ritardando or rallentando)

alt (Eng.).name: alt (Eng.)
alt (Eng.).definition: High; often refers to a particular range of voice, higher than a tenor but lower than a soprano

altissimo.name: altissimo
altissimo.definition: Very high; see also in altissimo

alto.name: alto
alto.definition: High; often refers to a particular range of voice, higher than a bass and lower than a soprano, the countertenor

am Steg (Ger.).name: am Steg (Ger.)
am Steg (Ger.).definition: At the bridge (i.e. playing a bowed string instrument near its bridge, which produces a heavier, stronger tone); see sul ponticello

ambitus.name: ambitus
ambitus.definition: The range between the highest and lowest notes of a given melody, part, or piece

andantino.name: andantino
andantino.definition: Slightly faster than andante (but earlier it is sometimes used to mean slightly slower than andante)

antiphon.name: antiphon
antiphon.definition: A liturgical or other composition consisting of choral responses, sometimes between two choirs; a passage of this nature forming part of another composition; a repeated passage in a psalm or other liturgical piece, similar to a refrain.

antiphonal.name: antiphonal
antiphonal.definition: A style of composition in which two sections of singers or instrumentalists exchange sections or music one after the other; typically the performers are on different sides of a hall or venue

appoggiatura.name: appoggiatura
appoggiatura.definition: One or more grace notes that take up some note value of the next full note.

arco.name: arco
arco.definition: The bow used for playing some string instruments (i.e. played with the bow, as opposed to pizzicato, in music for bowed instruments); normally used to cancel a pizzicato direction

aria.name: aria
aria.definition: Self-contained piece for one voice usually with orchestral accompaniment (which may be provided by a pianist using an orchestral reduction)

arioso.name: arioso
arioso.definition: Airy, or like an air (a melody) (i.e. in the manner of an aria); melodious

arpeggio.name: arpeggio
arpeggio.definition: played like a harp (i.e. the notes of the chords are to be played quickly one after another instead of simultaneously); in music for piano, this is sometimes a solution in playing a wide-ranging chord whose notes cannot be played otherwise; arpeggios are frequently used as an accompaniment; see also broken chord

arrangement.name: arrangement
arrangement.definition: An adaptation of a composition for other instruments, voices, or for another style of performance

articulation.name: articulation
articulation.definition: The transition or continuity between multiple notes

assai.name: assai
assai.definition: Very much, as in allegro assai, quite fast

attacca.name: attacca
attacca.definition: Attack or attach; go straight on (i.e. at the end of a movement, a direction to attach the next movement to the previous one, without a gap or pause). Often used as ' attacca subito ,' meaning a 'sudden' movement transition (literally, ' attack suddenly ').

B (Ger.).name: B (Ger.)
B (Ger.).definition: German for B flat (also in Swedish, Norwegian, Finnish, Icelandic, Danish, Croatian, Estonian and Hungarian); H in German is B natural

ballabile.name: ballabile
ballabile.definition: From the Italian Ballabile meaning 'danceable'. In ballet, the term refers to a dance which is performed by the corps de ballet. The term is rarely used today.

ballad.name: ballad
ballad.definition: A simple song, often of folk origin, usually consisting of quatrains using a common meter and rhyme scheme; a narrative poem suitable for singing, typically composed of quatrains in rhymed stanzas; a slow romantic or sentimental song.

ballata.name: ballata
ballata.definition: Dance (i.e. a piece of music suitable for dancing)

balletto.name: balletto
balletto.definition: Ballet (i.e. a theatrical work or entertainment in which ballet dancing and music, often with scenery and costumes, combine to tell a story, establish an emotional atmosphere, etc.)

barcarola.name: barcarola
barcarola.definition: Barcarole (i.e. a Venetian gondolier's song, or a piece of music composed in that style)

battuta.name: battuta
battuta.definition: Beat (i.e. the beat or pulse defines tempo by dividing time into pieces of equal duration)

ben marcato.name: ben marcato
ben marcato.definition: Well marked (i.e. execute each note fully and clearly, as if marching to the beat)

binary form.name: binary form
binary form.definition: A form comprising two sections, each of which is repeated: AABB

bolero.name: bolero
bolero.definition: A Spanish dance in simple triple time

bourrée.name: bourrée
bourrée.definition: A French dance in quick double time

bravura.name: bravura
bravura.definition: Great technical skill and brilliance shown in a performance or activity

burletta.name: burletta
burletta.definition: A comic opera; also, a suite of rustic dances

cabaletta.name: cabaletta
cabaletta.definition: A simple, catchy part of a melody

cadence.name: cadence
cadence.definition: A progression of at least two chords that concludes a phrase, section, or piece of music

cadenza.name: cadenza
cadenza.definition: Originally an improvised cadence by a soloist; later becoming an elaborate and written out passage in an aria or concerto, featuring the skills of an instrumentalist or vocalist

cancrizans.name: cancrizans
cancrizans.definition: A melodic line that is the reverse of a previously or simultaneously stated line

cantata.name: cantata
cantata.definition: Vocal genre for solo singers, chorus and instrumentalists (usually a small orchestra or a keyboard instrument) based on a lyric or dramatic poetic narrative. It generally consists of several movements including arias, recitatives and choruses.

capo.name: capo
capo.definition: Head; a direction in sheet music indicating a movement at the start (i.e. the beginning). The term is often abbreviated as D.C.

capriccio.name: capriccio
capriccio.definition: Whim or fancy, often used as a title for a piece of music, one that is lively and free in form

cavatina.name: cavatina
cavatina.definition: A short and simple melody performed by a soloist that is part of a larger piece

cesura.name: cesura
cesura.definition: A pause or interruption (e.g., a pause within a line of poetry)

chorale.name: chorale
chorale.definition: A hymn sung by the choir and congregation (often in unison)

col legno.name: col legno
col legno.definition: With the wood (i.e. the wooden back of the bow is drawn across the string(s), producing a muted percussive sound)

coloratura.name: coloratura
coloratura.definition: Elaborate ornamentation of vocal music written using many fast notes and trills

concertante.name: concertante
concertante.definition: A group of instruments accompanying a soloist or a principal theme

concertato.name: concertato
concertato.definition: Multiple voices or instruments independently elaborating upon the same melody

concertino.name: concertino
concertino.definition: The group of instruments in a concerto grosso that function as soloists; or, a short concerto

concerto.name: concerto
concerto.definition: An instrumental genre in which one or more soloists play with and against a larger orchestra

con fuoco.name: con fuoco
con fuoco.definition: With fire, in a fiery manner

contralto.name: contralto
contralto.definition: The lowest female voice or voice part, intermediate between soprano and tenor

da capo (D.C.).name: da capo (D.C.)
da capo (D.C.).definition: From the beginning (i.e. return to the start of the piece)

dal segno (D.S.).name: dal segno (D.S.)
dal segno (D.S.).definition: From the sign (i.e. return to a place in the music designated by the sign)

droit (Fr.).name: droit (Fr.)
droit (Fr.).definition: Right, as in 'main droit', right hand

ecossaise (Fr.).name: ecossaise (Fr.)
ecossaise (Fr.).definition: Scottish (i.e. a type of country dance in quick 2/4 time)

encore (Fr.).name: encore (Fr.)
encore (Fr.).definition: Again (i.e. perform the relevant passage once more)

enharmonic.name: enharmonic
enharmonic.definition: An enharmonic equivalent is one of two or more notation methods for writing the same pitch

estinto.name: estinto
estinto.definition: Extinct, extinguished, as soft as possible, lifeless

etude (Fr.).name: etude (Fr.)
etude (Fr.).definition: Study (i.e. a composition designed to train a musician technically as well as musically)

fantasia.name: fantasia
fantasia.definition: Fantasy, usually a free-form musical composition

fermata.name: fermata
fermata.definition: Pause, hold, stop (i.e. a hold or pause)

fine.name: fine
fine.definition: End, as in 'al fine', to the end

flautando.name: flautando
flautando.definition: Flute-like, i.e. to play a bowed string instrument in the manner of a flute (by bowing lightly and close to the fingerboard)

grace note.name: grace note
grace note.definition: An extra note added as an embellishment and not essential to the harmony or melody

hauptstimme (Ger.).name: hauptstimme (Ger.)
hauptstimme (Ger.).definition: Main voice, chief part; often the highest part

homophony.name: homophony
homophony.definition: Music in which one voice has the melody, and the others accompany

instrumentation.name: instrumentation
instrumentation.definition: Arrangement of music for a combined number of instruments

interlude.name: interlude
interlude.definition: A short piece of instrumental music played between scenes in a play or opera

intermezzo.name: intermezzo
intermezzo.definition: Interlude, short movement or section in a larger work

intonation.name: intonation
intonation.definition: The rise and fall of the voice in speaking

inversion.name: inversion
inversion.definition: A melody that is turned upside down

mazurka (It.).name: mazurka (It.)
mazurka (It.).definition: A Polish folk dance in triple meter

metronome.name: metronome
metronome.definition: An instrument to mark time by means of regularly recurring ticks or flashes at adjustable intervals

mezzo-soprano.name: mezzo-soprano
mezzo-soprano.definition: A female voice that is lower than a soprano but higher than an alto

motet.name: motet
motet.definition: A short piece of sacred choral music, typically polyphonic and unaccompanied

musette (Fr.).name: musette (Fr.)
musette (Fr.).definition: A small bagpipe used in the French court, a pastoral dance

neoclassical.name: neoclassical
neoclassical.definition: Music that is characterized by aesthetic order, clarity, and equilibrium

octave.name: octave
octave.definition: Interval between one musical pitch and another with half or double its frequency

pastorale (It.).name: pastorale (It.)
pastorale (It.).definition: Pastoral, in a simple and tranquil manner

polyphony.name: polyphony
polyphony.definition: Music with two or more independent lines

polyrhythm.name: polyrhythm
polyrhythm.definition: Two or more rhythms being played simultaneously

program music.name: program music
program music.definition: Music that is intended to evoke images or convey the impression of events

quintet.name: quintet
quintet.definition: A composition for five voices or instruments

rhapsody.name: rhapsody
rhapsody.definition: A free instrumental composition in one extended movement, typically one that is emotional or exuberant in character

rondo.name: rondo
rondo.definition: A musical form with a recurring leading theme, often found in the final movement of a sonata or concerto

rubato (It.).name: rubato (It.)
rubato (It.).definition: Free adjustment of tempo for expressive purposes

suite.name: suite
suite.definition: A set of instrumental compositions, originally in dance style, to be played in succession

sul tasto (It.).name: sul tasto (It.)
sul tasto (It.).definition: On the fingerboard (i.e. playing a stringed instrument near the head, producing a softer tone)

sul ponticello (It.).name: sul ponticello (It.)
sul ponticello (It.).definition: On the bridge (i.e. playing a stringed instrument near the bridge, producing a heavy, strong tone)

sustain.name: sustain
sustain.definition: To hold a note for its full length

theme.name: theme
theme.definition: A melodic or, sometimes a harmonic idea presented in a musical form

timbre.name: timbre
timbre.definition: The quality of a sound that distinguishes one voice or instrument from another

tonic.name: tonic
tonic.definition: The first note of a scale

trill.name: trill
trill.definition: A rapid alternation between two adjacent notes, usually a semitone or tone apart, which can be identified with the context of the trill

trio.name: trio
trio.definition: A composition for three voices or instruments

triplet.name: triplet
triplet.definition: Three notes played in the same amount of time as one or two beats

unison.name: unison
unison.definition: Two or more voices or instruments playing the same note simultaneously

ut (Fr.).name: ut (Fr.)
ut (Fr.).definition: The syllable used in solfège to represent the tonic

vamp.name: vamp
vamp.definition: To repeat a short, simple passage of music
